posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked:
The text describes the development and features of the MK4T TwERVE, a modified version of the traditional Swerve module designed to improve performance on rough terrain. The original Swerve drive mechanism struggles with handling obstacles larger than 1.5 inches, particularly on soft surfaces. The MK4T addresses this limitation by increasing the drive ratio to 80% of the standard setting, allowing it to climb obstacles up to 45 degrees without modification. This improvement enables vehicles equipped with MK4T TwERVE to navigate challenging environments more effectively compared to their standard counterparts.

The MK4T achieves this enhanced capability through a conservative design approach, minimizing changes to the existing Mk4i framework to ensure simplicity for manufacturers and users. Key features include a 3-axis CNC mill with tool changers, a lathe for precise adjustments, and a 1/2-inch aluminum plate stock construction. Despite its advanced capabilities, the MK4T maintains compatibility with standard wiring and components, requiring minimal reconfiguration.

Four distinct configurations cater to different needs: Regular On-center, Regular Off-center, Suspension On-center, and Suspension Off-center. Each offers unique advantages and trade-offs, balancing factors like steering ability, mechanical complexity, and drive ratios. For instance, the On-center configurations prioritize ease of use and reduced complexity, while the Off-center and suspension options focus on versatility for specific applications.

The development of MK4T was motivated by AntPoison, whose assistance in refining the text and formatting is acknowledged. The project aims to push the boundaries of what's possible with Swerve modules, offering solutions for enthusiasts and builders looking to enhance their vehicles' performance on rough terrain.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: This looks very impressive; I'm going to try cadding one for max swerve now.

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: If you make a copy of my doc, it might be possible to just modify mine to fit maxswerve, idk tho i’ve never used maxswerve. (Or you can just make your own)

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: This is quite cool! Would love to see this implemented IRL. The suspension ones in particular are crazy! I see a few minor issues but the designs are excellent! So you mentioned additional forces on the bearing and I wanted to explore that here. The standard SDS modules are about 3.635" from the main bearing to the floor. Based on your models 5.006" for the fixed centered 5.855" for the fixed offset 6.395" for the suspension centered and 7.822" for the suspension offset. That’s anywhere between 38% and 115% increased bearing loading.Granted the suspension ones very likely decrease the instantaneous forces as the gas shock disperses the force to the bearing over a longer period of time but any side-loads will still see that increased force. Obviously it’s hard to predict the forces that are seen in FRC but I would be surprised if these bearings could survive an entire season with 2x the load a standard module has.

Where can you find a treaded timing belt similar to the one designed for your application? I have only seen similar products available on Andymark for their drives, but they appear to be too long for this particular design.

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

Alibaba.com provides Guangzhou Goodly Industry Belt Co., Ltd., which offers products such as timing belts, V-belts, conveyor belts, foamed sponge belts, and molded coated belts. A recent quote indicates a price of $21 per unit, significantly lower than the $400 per unit offered by an American company, making it a reasonable price point.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: This comes from a software dude mindset, a place of ignorance. Would you want the 'track shape' to be a symmetric 'diamond' otherwise you may have a flat face against an obstacle? Vs the 45-degree angle? Also because some swerve code optimizes rotation setpoints to prevent '>90 degree' rotations. With the asymmetric shape wouldn't that be a concern?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: Have you done any calculations on the steering torque needed for the offset versions? It may not be as hard for the software as you think. That said, if a future programming team wanted to get really deep, there was some speculation years ago that a “caster” swerve could maybe outperform a regular module because it could change directions faster.

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: The raw kinematic model of swerve does not have that optimization, so it would be as simple as disabling the optimization in whatever library you are using.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: Well sure, but would it not be an improvement to make it symmetric? Other than the weight / size increase? Why do we always have to 'fix it' in code?

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: In theory, yes, but then you can’t run corner-biased modules because it can’t start inside the frame perimeter.

posts.name: Kira (he/she/they)
posts.cooked: I clicked on this expecting decagon wheels and a billet 7071 frame. This is actually pretty cool.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: Ah, I didn't think about that. Looking back, I see what you mean by extending the frame's perimeter.
Did they give you an idea of what the turn-around time was on a custom order?

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: The quote indicates that it will be ready within 7 to 10 business days after payment.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but the tires reside fully within the bumper zone. The bumpers should generally rest directly against the frame. Wouldn't the front modules interfere with the bumpers when moving forward?

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: My assumption is that if it's a terrain game, the rules would allow high bumper configurations, similar to what we saw in Stronghold.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: Since 3D printed tread has seen popularity, I would be very interested to see if it would last. However, I am very concerned about proceeding with manufacturing during the season without off-season testing.

posts.name: Evan Sigl
posts.cooked: cad.onshape.com Onshape the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users Configurable belt for printing i might add spikes later if i feel like it

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: If we don’t undertake something during the season, we will definitely explore this as an off-season project.
